review_title: If You're Good At What You Do, Do It Elsewhere
pros:
Pros are entirely team-based. If you have a good team, your day-to-day might be tolerable.

Fortune 500 company, which looks good to some other employers when you look for real opportunity elsewhere.
cons:
Where to begin...

AutoNation is lightyears behind on technology and processes, and it's not going to get better any time soon. 

Executive leadership (with a few small exceptions) is out of their depth in the current consumer environment. They think automotive sales is special and can still be run the way it was in the 1970s. See the dubious tenure of Carl Liebert (who was fired for thinking he could actually be the CEO). They're simply not ready to move forward.

Employee pricing on vehicles is a joke. Every dealership you go to will start by telling you they can get you a better deal without the corporate pricing structure. Once you look at the numbers, it's clear that they're trying to screw you like any standard dealer. This is the company culture. It's not a team, and if it were, you're not on it.

Certain areas work as legitimate meritocracies, but good luck finding that out before you start. More likely, you'll end up in a group where advancement is based on personal connections (exclusively) with no regard at all to the ability to do the job.

Contractors - AVOID THIS PLACE. No matter what they tell you about converting to full-time, they rarely do so. If you like contracting, go for it (if you don't care about anything listed above). If you want to be on staff, look anywhere else.

Benefits are a joke. Expensive healthcare options, ridiculously low 401(k) match (50% of 4% - 2% max). 

Don't expect regular or decent raises. There's always an excuse or delay, probably related to a mass-firing of director-level and above talent (which you would expect to free up some money).
Advice to Management
The old guard needs to retire, starting with Mike Jackson. This is not the consumer environment they grew up in, and they're not dynamic enough to shift with the times. Until this happens, AutoNation is going to continue to disappoint employees and shareholders. Not to mention that Cheryl Miller isn't going to be able to run the company with MJ pulling the strings.
